text.content: The Role of Early Childhood Professionals
Click a Lesson or Activity to learn more about Encouraging Verbal Communication.
Many parents may not even realize all of the subtle ways they nurture their child's healthy social, emotional, and cognitive development.
You have the unique opportunity to explain the importance of everyday interactions parents and caregivers share with the infants in their care.

You can educate parents about early communication with infants by:

Helping parents to recognize the communicative signals of their infants.

Pointing out and reinforcing positive communication behaviors many parents instinctively engage in.

Explaining why and how these interactions stimulate language acquisition and create a foundation for literacy.

Providing additional ways for parents and caregivers to nurture their children's communication skills.

Key Messages:
  • Responding to babies when they try to communicate with either verbal expression or physical gestures helps to foster their healthy social, emotional, language, and cognitive development.
  • Parents and caregivers play a vital role in helping young children develop their communication skills.

graphic.notes: early childhood professional talking with parents
Early childhood professional talking with parent as they play with child

audio.transcript: Many parents may not even realize all of the subtle ways they nurture their child's healthy social, emotional, and cognitive development.

As an early childhood professional, you have the unique opportunity to explain the importance of everyday interactions parents and caregivers share with the infants in their care. Through your relationship with parents and caregivers, you can help equip these adults with the knowledge, understanding, and tools to support even the youngest children's blossoming communication skills.

You can educate parents about early communication with infants by: Helping parents to recognize the communicative signals of their infants, whether it is to attend to an infant's points, looks, or babbles; that is, helping parents to "see" that the infant is communicating and that there are opportunities for social interaction. Pointing out and reinforcing the positive communication behaviors many parents instinctively engage in with their children. Explaining why and how these interactions stimulate language acquisition and create a foundation for literacy. And providing additional ways for parents and caregivers to nurture their children's communication skills.

Before we continue, remember the Key Messages for this section are: Responding to babies when they try to communicate with either verbal expression or physical gestures helps to foster their healthy social, emotional, language, and cognitive development. And parents and caregivers play a vital role in helping young children develop their communication skills.
